oai_dc:dc.dc:title: WPA bookmobile
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mimeographed page contains two original black and white photographs. The top photo is of a woman and two children looking at books in a mobile library. It is identified as the "WPA bookmobile in the Watts Barr [sic] Dam Defense Area covering Rhea, Rhone [sic], Loudon, and Meigs Counties." The bottom photo shows a WPA mobile library parked outside Stewart's Cash Grocery. Children wait in line. The truck is identified as the WPA bookmobile sponsored by the Nashville Public Library. These pictures, between pages 7 and 8, are stapled to the page.

The Work Projects Administration (WPA, formerly Works Progress Administration) infused funds into many libraries. In rural areas of Kentucky and the Appalachians, librarians often used horses as mobile libraries. Marshall Stewart was the Tennessee state supervisor for the Library Service Program. The photos are from the annual report issued for 1940-1941.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Federal Works Agency, Work Projects Administration
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: New Deal, 1933-1939--Tennessee ; Nashville Public Library; Mobile Public Library; United States. Works Progress Administration
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stewart, D. Marshall
